instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message:
Clean board, boots up but wont charge on any of the ports, USB data only works on 1 port.

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> only get 5V and 0.250A
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> both are 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_ISOL</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> 1.8V
Already replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and made no difference, I'm hesitant to replace <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

UB300 and UB400 both get 20V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on LDO ports between left/right <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Also check <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and its traces/resistors.
Remove connectors from shell and inspect USB-C terminals on the bad side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>

All the above are almost identical readings in Diode mode compared to left right sides.

<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> was replaced before making the post, I forgot to mention.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message:
Was <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> affected by corrosion?
Check all its traces and adjacent resistors.
Did you replace with one from donor, same model?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message: No, board is clean no signs of corrosion, but <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> I knew was related to the problem so I replaced it, first with one from different board model, than later after reading your last post, from the same model board and same problem, I also end up replacing the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and checked all resistors around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, all of them are good, but no change at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message:
You said to get 20V on two ports, but USB activity one port only.
So there must be a problem on these ports area too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message: Al resistors around UB090 were fine and all LDO were fine also on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> that had the 20V, but I replaced UB090 and now I have USB-Activity on both ports on that side, but the other side still only 5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
threads.message: May have problems with <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, or some broken resistor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2 ports 20V 2 Ports 5V
